reviewText: This game mixes great fun with that anticapation of getting that amazing legendary item. Just the joy that you have slicing and slashing through hordes of mythological creatures, including Satyrs, Harpies, Cyclops, Typhon, the most powerful titan, and even the king of the underworld himself; Hades. You will not only enjoy fighting your most darkest adversaries, but also finding the most epic of loot. This game features thousands of different items you can find across the land. Speaking of land, this game takes place over Ancient Greece, Egypt, and Asia. At each stop, different opponents will greet you (by that I mean try and rip you to shreds). Not only is this game fun, but it is also a type of learning game. Like me, I found out about a lot of Ancient Greek mythology by playing this game. Most areas in this game are real places in this geographical area of the world. For example, in the first act (Greece) some of the towns include Delphi, Athens, Sparta, etc. The boss fights are also exhilarating. After almost every main boss there is a chest (or in some cases an orb) which can be opened, and in them are magical items that when dropping are completely randomized. Because of this randomization, every time you play, you should expect a new experience to emerge. Each time you play, you find new items, become a new hero, and save the world. The multiplayer works out fine, but when playing with friends, I recommend sharing your classes so that you can come up with the best class setup between you. What are the classes you ask? The classes include Storm, Earth, Warfare, Spirit, Defense, Hunting, Nature, and Rogue. Once you reach level two, you can pick your first class. Then, at level eight, you can pick your second class. After that, you will no longer be able to choose a different class on the same character. It's a fun game and truly does bring out the adventerous side of you. Mortals, save all of humanity in... Titan Quest!\n\nEDIT: Multiplayer is no longer a key feature of the game. It will be required of you to install outside programs to play with your friends. Sorry if this may've been an inconveniance for you.

reviewText:
Titan Quest is the quintessential Diablo clone. There are so many similarities in both features and execution that you might catch yourself wondering if this is how Diablo 3 would have looked if Blizzard didn't insist on only releasing sequels 5+ years after the last sale is made. There are several problems however that keep it out of the same league as Diablo though.

Titan Quest is a classic click until your fingers fall off action RPG in the by now classic style of Diablo. The formula feels so familiar by now that playing any incarnation of the genre without any new additions makes you almost forget which game you're actually playing.

The ancient Greek backdrop is quite pretty even if the mythology has been somewhat perverted for the sake of making it into a gaming experience, the tried and true lore of said civilization makes for some above average questing and dialog however. Although that is of course never really that much of a deciding factor in a game like this.

The character building system of just starting you out as a guy in a tunic and only opening up for more intricate customizing as you gain more levels further down the line works quite well but it doesn't really add anything new to the genre. You will still end up with the supercharged min-max character that absolutely destroys everything in a way your first character could only dream of.

The game is quite pretty and the enemies are fairly varied even if they are just ancient Greek variations of things we already know.

The problem with Titan Quest isn't as much that it does something wrong, it's that it everything it does right has already been done right by so many games before it. There is very little new to the formula and it makes the game feel as just another stopgap meant to satisfy the market while Blizzard remembers how to make sequels.

reviewText:
Some say this is the best of the Diablo 2 clones with better graphics.  The base game is eight years old now and having played newer titles like Torchlight 2, Dungeon Siege 2 and 3  as well as others, I think that's selling it a bit short.  It's held up well although you won't find features now taken for granted like player customization, Steam achievements, automapping and multiplayer party features.  The game is engaging and challenging but just enough to keep pulling you along.  There are no 20 minute play sessions, more like a few hours or more.

The game looks great, the maps are interesting but sometimes it does seem a bit long between merchants and you can run out of health potions quickly.  When that happens it can be a bit of a grind but at least you get XP for your trouble.  The camera angles are failry limited but you can zoom in and out.  There are times I wish I had more control of the camera but it doesn't really get in the way of playing the game.  Unlike Dungeon Siege 3 whose camera controls were so bad they made the game unplayable with their wild random swings.   Titan Quests stays locked on in comparison.

If I had one complaint in the single player it would be the combat system.  You're forced to fight one enemy at a time even if you're going up against 30 baddies.  You spend a lot of time selecting individual opponents and chugging health potions to get through it.  At least I haven't been trapped by a such a group.  There always seems to be an avenue to run away when needed and the baddies  only chase you for a short time.

The ability to save on the fly is great but expect to have to hack through everything you already dispatched again when you come back.  I kind of like things I kill to stay dead in the same game.  Altough to it's credit if you don't leave the game session,  dead things will stay dead.  I just wish the saves would follow suit.  It's another example of how the game can be a bit of a grind in some places.

You can customize weapons and armor with enchantments and the inventory system is very much like torchlight or any other RPG with inventory slots set up in a grid.  The skills tree is easy enough to understand but the game is a bit stingy with skill points meaning your special abilities won't do you much good till you're done with the game.  It can be annoying to get beaten by a lower level enemy who has a special ability that you're nowhere near achieving.

There is fast travel capability that you can use on the fly which is something I liked in Torchlight 2  and Dungeon Siege 2 where you can leave and then transport back to exactly where you were. That's a time saver and potentially a life saver when you run out of health potions or fill up you rinventory with loot.

If this game really falls down anywhere, however,  it's the multiplayer/co-op gameplay.  Yes it has LAN play which is welcome but unlike newer games in this genre XP and loot aren't shared. between players  Which means if you're level 3 and you go into a game with a level 16 player all they can really do for you is play bodyguard which means there's not much in it for them.  The loot drops don't level with the player either so often times you'll pick up items you won't be able to use or are useless scarp metal.  Although that's a common complaint in RPG's and not just Titan Quest.

In the end even with its flaws I really liked this game and the benefits far outweigh the annoyances and goes in the list of my top 3 favorite RPG's so far.

Titan Quest is an excellent click 'n' slash game set  in a well rendered  ancient Hellenic   setting, with  lots of believable mythological  characters such as Satyrs the odd Cyclops and giant spiders that  are exquisitely animated. The world really  does look beautiful even with its pseudo 3D isometric look (with a touch of camera zoom  that allows you get  get  close upand almost personal).

Jogging into a camp full  of beasts and butchering them with an axe feels amazingly  satisfying. Playing in Co-op or SP both allow you  to   take on   hordes of monsters, or  valiantly struggle against a dozen Ray Harryhausen skeletons or a grumpy gorgon, especially once you've gained  some    XP.

You can  transfer all of your  booty over from SP to MP play, and as with all RPG's,  upgrading your character to  carry more goodies is a must do.  You'll soon find yourself kitted out in  the   snaziest of  armour and the  best  of  weapons a warrior could  want.

TQ is a hack and slash RPG much like Diablo. You run around clicking monsters to kill them

GENERAL GAMEPLAY INFORMATION
I wanted to make a section to tell you about general gameplay features and facts to aid you as you read this review. The max level in TQ is 65 and IT increases it to 75. When you level you gain 3 skill points and 2 attribute points to spend how you like. The attribute points can be used to increase your max health or energy

or intelligence. There are 3 difficulty levels with the next highest one being unlocked after beating the game on the previous difficulty.

What is nice and something you don't often see in these kinds of games is that there are more characters you can speak to than just the quest givers. These extra characters will tell you a little bit about something

The skills are where this game really shines. How it works is that at the beginning of the game you select your gender and start the game. Upon your first level you can select your first skill mastery. There are 8 skill masteries in TQ
column23: with a 9th one added in the expansion IT. When you reach level 8 you can select your 2nd and final skill mastery. Each mastery has many different skills you can learn such as passive skills
column25: and ones that stay active for a certain reserved energy cost. Each skill can be upgraded with points many times
column27: making the skill better and better. When you level up you get 3 skill points to play with which I really enjoy. I much prefer having more skill points and longer skill advancement than fewer points and shorter

column31: and attributes; I believe a unique feature to this game. As you can imagine this enables for massive replayability to try out all the different skill mastery combinations.\n\nThe only downside is that at least a few skills in each mastery are just plain useless or have limited usefulness. Loot is the main focus of these kinds of games and this game does not disappoint. There are several different tiers of loot with the higher tiers of course being harder to find. There are also vendors who occasionally sell good items

but the best loot is always found. Higher difficulties will reward even better loot and more set items and uniques. There are also relics and charms dropped by monsters which you can add to your equipment to make them stronger. Higher difficulties have better relics and charms.

There are 4 acts in the game with the expansion and each act has many unique monsters for you to fight. Although the monsters aren't palette swapped

their behavior and attack patterns generally don't change much. This isn't a big surprise though. The different monsters do have their own unique drops that you won't find from other monsters. reviewText:
The game is basically Diablo II in every aspect, only set in Ancient Grease and with 3D assets. It has everything from random and unique item drops to randomly generated levels. It is nearly identical to the classic Bliizard game. The key difference however is the class system.

Unlike Diablo II where you pick your class from at the beginning, Titan Quest has your character start with base stats and abilities. As you progress your character to lv10, you are given the option to pick a job class of your choosing. Additionally, you choose a secondary job class later in the game that works in conjucton with the spells and abilities of your primary class.

To sum it up, if you ever felt Diablo III didn’t fully capture the magic of its predecessor and Trine left you wanting more, then you will absolutely love this game.

Also get the expansion. Otherwise what’s the point.

I picked this game up a while back on sale, but it was always the game I *almost* played.  I finally gave it a shot and couldn't be happier with my experience so far.  I have played a lot of top-down, Diablo-esque type games - but this one is top 3 if not the best one I have played.  The UI is very easy to understand, the tutorial is helpful without being overbearing, and there are so many of the little things done right that puts this game at a very high level of playability and enjoyability.

Item comparisions in game without having to compare or drop equipment, color-coding items, being able to zoom in and out in real time, a very easy and intuitive mouse and keyboard control, and the list goes on and on.  I am going to be spending a lot more time in this game and its DLC.  Progressing through the game is tough but there hasn't been a challenge yet a few extra health potions hasn't cured.  The increase in difficulty is fun without being basic.  If you're a fan of the top-down games like Diablo etc, if you enjoy the Greek mythology, or if you're looking to try a game which is just very comfortable to play, then this is something you really should try.

A note about the servers - yes, they are down so you can't do multi-player from the game.  However, this game is one that is covered by Game Ranger - so within 10 minutes my friend and I downloaded that free program and had a LAN connection and were in game, having a blast.

TL;DR: Yes.  This one is definitely worth it!

Gorgeous looking, highly addictive RPG. Titan Quest is a polished and lengthy game with plenty of ancient monsters to slay and gargantuan amounts of loot. The environments look and feel diverse and amazingly detailed. Enemy models are intricately detailed. You have weapons and spells at your disposal and can choose 2 of several classes in order to create your character. It's not as deep and bound for infinite replayability like Diablo 2 but you can consider this as its much more approachable clone with a very nice learning curve.

My only complaint comes from the looting system: You can't compare or even view dropped items' properties when they are on the ground. Therefore you'll need to pick items up in order to see their stats which becomes a huge pain as you constantly have to manage your inventory and throw items out of your inventory in order to make space for that new item you found for comparison.

All in all, absolutely fun game with lengthy campaign and level editor. If you're into games like Diablo or Torchlight, You really can't go wrong with Titan Quest.

Let me start by saying, ignore the 'lack' of playing time......
I am a seasoned gamer in the RPG point and click series of games, and I must admit, I am really pleased that I got this game.

Diablo III, sacred 2, Land of exile, neverwinter etc all brilliant, but I love Greek mythology and love this game because of that. It's fun when playing online with a friend or 2 (although has to be done on Tunngle) but that is a small mishap. The game was well worthy of it's value, 75% off I got it for, and for value alone it is the best, I would even had paid the full price TBH. The characters in the game are easily upgraded, and the best of it is, you don't spend seemingly hours in character screen, as with other titlles. The skills tree is easily done too, and lets you choose different types of powers.

All in all an excellent game I would recommend....even more so with the expansion pack!!!!

reviewText:
he game Titan Quest (also known as TQ) is what this wiki is all about. The videogame is in the action role-playing game (RPG) genre, with an adjustable isometric player view.

It has one expansion pack: Titan Quest: Immortal Throne (also known as TQIT) . The Titan Quest Gold Edition is a version that includes the original game and the Titan Quest: Immortal Throne expansion pack. Both the game and its expansion were developed by Iron Lore, which later went out of business.

Titan Quest is an Action RPG often deemed to be a Diablo II clone, only with better graphics. While the former claim is not exactly true, the game does have a similar playing style as its predecessor. Being programmed in a much later date than Diablo II, Titan Quest uses 3D graphics, has its action set in mythological Greece, Egypt and Orient, and is rated the best Diablo clones.

For gamers who want to start playing Titan Quest and the Immortal Throne expansion, both can be had in the combined Titan Quest Gold Edition pack. As of April 21st, 2009, the Gold Edition sells for about $10 on online stores like Amazon.com - a sixth of the price of buying the original Titan Quest and the Immortal Throne expansion separately .

Ultimately, games like this are all about the loot.  Unfortunately, in Titan Quest, the loot is really, really boring.  99% of drops are going to be left on the ground.  It appears that once you beat the game on normal, set items, and other decent gear drops when you play the game on the next difficulty setting.  No way I am putting any more time in to find out.

My major issue with the game was the fact that it was extremely easy right up until the final boss battle.  30+ hours in and I died twice.  I got to the last battle and couldn't do anything to the Titan boss.  I don't mind hard games, but make the difficulty linear, not all of a sudden.  I looked up strategies and the most recommended was an exploit.  No thanks.

The game does have some positives.  The skill trees are interesting, and some of the creature models and locations are fun.  Oddly though, for such an old game my video card was going nuts processing it.

So with 30+ hours in, I cannot recommend this game.  I usually like to finish games regardless of how bad they are, but I am not willing to sink anymore time in this one.

reviewText: Titan Quest wants to be a fun hack n slash RPG in the style of Diablo.  Sadly, it suffers from a host of issues that make it a flawed and frustrating game.  Patient (stubborn) gamers who don't mind spending time grinding levels might enjoy it.  It is well worth one's time to read up on a couple user-made FAQs and guides before starting.  Picking the right skills is key, and the game has little advice on the subject.  TQ offers a lot of gameplay for the price, but much of that will not precisely qualify as 'fun.'  It takes a fair amount to time to get to a sufficiently high level and gather powerful enough gear to advance the main quest.\n\nTorchlight is a more enjoyable and better looking game and I would heartily recommend it first.  Bastion is better still and my top choice for the hack n slash genre.  Having played those, TQ is not a bad game to pick up on sale, especially for a seasoned CRPG player with a stubborn streak.  It does run pretty well on older hardware.

reviewText:
IT's TITAN SMITE'N TIME
If you're familiar with games like Diablo or Torchlight then you're familiar with the basic mechanics and presentation of this game.  If you liked those games, you'll probably like this game. I say probably because this game made a few errors in their attempt to improve upon the genre.

The Good

The presentation and graphics are nice. And I mean really nice.

The areas are large and reward exploration. You will find all sorts of little monster camps and loot aches.



The Bad
The skill system is rather lazily implemented. You see, while it allows you to pick a primary and secondary class there's actually little difference between the classes, furthermore, there's no in game bonus for choosing a different combination. You know like how in diablo or Torchlight  you could trigger different dialog depending on the class, even different quests. Not so here. So while in theory you have dozens of class combinations and potentially as many play-styles, it is merely an illusion.

The Animatiuons, though crisp, are also repetitive. In that the difference between two special  attacks can at times be minisculwe

The save system is horrendous. I mean really horrendous. the maps are huge and open but since the save and warp points are sooo far away, you get alot of fatigue built up because once you start out, you face two choices.  Quit and wind up restarting at the last respawn point that was maybe two zones back. Or Keep going to the next warp point which may be another two zones away. This can make travesal a bit of a chore.

All in all it is still a good solid game and I can recommend with no shame, just maybe consider games like Torchlight or The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing before you pick this one up. You'll likely be happier with those.

Ingredients
2 large eggs
Salt and pepper
2 to 3 tablespoons shredded cheese (optional)
1/4 to 1/2 cup filling, pre-cooked if necessary (optional)
2 teaspoons unsalted butter
Minced parsley, to garnish (optional)

Equipment
Mixing bowl
Whisk
8-inch nonstick skillet
Spatula
Dinner plate

Instructions
1. Whisk the eggs: Crack both eggs into a mixing bowl. Whisk the eggs until completely combined, and season with salt and pepper. If you're adding cheese or other fillings, make sure they are prepped and nearby.
2. Warm the skillet and melt the butter: Place an 8-inch skillet over medium-high heat and melt the butter. Tilt the skillet as the butter melts to evenly coat the bottom. When the butter stops sizzling, the pan is heated and ready.
3. Pour the eggs into the skillet: Pour the whisked eggs into the skillet. Immediately tilt the pan so the eggs coat the entire bottom. The eggs should sizzle on contact; if not, continue cooking, but remember to heat the pan a little longer next time.
4. Drag and push the eggs to form waves: Use a spatula to gently drag and push the cooked eggs from the edges toward the center of the pan, making space for the uncooked eggs and forming waves in the omelette. Tilt the skillet so that the uncooked eggs flow into the open spaces.
5. Cook the omelette for 1 to 2 minutes: The omelette will finish cooking in 1 to 2 minutes. When done, the bottom will be set and the edges will look crisp. The top of the omelette should still look fairly wet and uncooked, but there will no longer be any loose, easily flowing liquid egg — the omelette will continue cooking off the heat, so finish when you think the top still seems a bit underdone.
6. Top with cheese and fillings: If using, sprinkle the cheese and fillings down the center of the omelette.
7. Fold the omelette: Fold the bottom third of the omelette over the center, and then fold the top third down. Alternatively, fold the omelette in half.
8. Slide the omelette onto a plate: Gently slide the omelette onto a plate and garnish with parsley. Eat right away while still hot.

reviewText:
I have serious issues with this game. Maybe I've been spoiled by Skyrim but this game is just not fun for me. My biggest issue is the inventory system. The inventory system should be a minor portion of the game experience but its major in this game. It's icon based like Divinity II and Deus Ex but unlike Divinity II you are only given 60 icon slots and one magic staff takes up 10 of them (17%). And unlike Deus Ex you can't rotate items around to try to fit them in so you can never use up all of the slots. So you end up spending most of your time going back and forth between vendors and the environment.

When dealing with vendors you basically have three choices:
Do I spend half my gold to buy an item that is only marginally better than the item I have but I can use it right now?
Do I spend all of my gold to buy an item that is significantly better than the item I have and keep it in my limited inventory for about three level-ups before I can use it (and hope that something better doesn't come along in the mean time)?
Do I buy nothing at all and hope for a better drop somewhere (knowing that better drops are few and far between)?
In 11+ hours of play I have opted for number three all but once.

When not dealing with vendors the combat (and navigation) is just a series of left clicks with a couple of right clicks and 0-9 spell casts thrown in... Meh.

The quests and the map are completely linear with typically one major and one minor quest target at any one time. So your only decisions in the game are do I do the major quest first or the minor quest first? But it doesn't matter what you choose because there are no quest targets on the map. But don't worry, the map is small enough that you won't have to wander around long before you stumble upon one of the quest targets.

Plan on playing for at least an hour or two each session unless you like killing the same enemies over and over again because it's checkpoint based. There is a Save button in the Options menu but I haven't figured out what it does. No matter where you save you will respawn at the latest checkpoint (rebirth fountain) you have found the next time you start the game.

I'm giving up now to try something else. I'll start a fifth play-through of Skyrim before I'll try this game again.

Glenowen.

reviewText: Titan Quest is a mixed bag. With a few exceptions, it's a mediocre dungeon crawler. The two-class system is great and allows for a lot of customization. You pick one of eight classes when you start a character, and a second class at level 8. After that, you are free to put points into either classes' skill trees as you see fit. Unfortunately, the enjoyability of this system is hindered by excrutiatingly slow progress. I stuck with it for 36 hours, which only got me about 20 levels and half way through the campaign. The main problem with level progression comes from the skill point system. Each level, you are given 3 skill points. This seems like a lot, but you also have to put these points into your classes to unlock skill tiers. This means that if you put one point into each class every level, you only get one point per level for your skills until the classes cap at 32. Keep in mind that after 36 hours, I only reached level 21. Aside from the leveling system and ancient Greek setting, Titan Quest is generic in every way. It really isn't a bad game, but the painfully slow advancement will drive away all but the most dedicated of players.

Yes, it is a lot like Diablo II, and that isn't even one of its top ten problems. Performance issues aside ( I own a midrange computer anyway), this game ain't that great.

Let's first talk about the squandered setting. Ancient Greece, Egypt, Persia and China sound like magnificent places to have a good old hack-n-slash. And in the beginning you're fighting satyrs and cyclops. Good start. Then the skeletons come. And the birds. And the boars. And the tiger creatures. And the rat creatures. Yawn.  Also most of the game is spent traversing generic countryside while traveling from city to city; the landscape has its waterfall-and-rope-bridge moments, but it's basically boring grassland after boring forest followed by boring desert and boring mountains. And the monsters are exactly what you would expect to find in those places based on almost every other hack-n-slash I've ever played. The game is quite long for the money and some of the cities and temples are cool (if few and VERY far between), but it might as well be based in modern-day America.
The gameplay is balls-boring slash-loot-repeat. The only interesting bits are when you summon minions to help with the fighting, but then when said summoning skill is leveled up enough you'll find that the minions are doing most of the fighting for you. It's hard to put my finger on what makes me not recommend Titan Quest.  Two things make it very difficult for me to even complete the game: (1) Too many passives abilities vs active abilities make you feel less in control of the combat,  (2)  Potions have no cooldown, so the only strategy you need to employ is having enough potions for any given fight.

Because of that the combat feels bland and repetitive from quite an early point in the game, and I just can't be bothered to finish it.

On the plus side, the graphics are quite good.  Combat feels nice and responsive, especially with the weight added by the physics engine.  The story is okay, with decent voice acting.  The skill trees are interesting, especially as you can combine any two core classes.

I'm looking forward to Grim Dawn, the spiritual successor to Titan Quest from the same developers.  Hopefully, that game will deliver where Titan Quest does not.

reviewText:
The action RPG fundamentals are all there:  diverse character classes, hack-and-slash gameplay, and a never-ending quest for better gear.  However, Titian Quest is full of so many small flaws that add up to a seriously flawed game that's difficult to enjoy.

From the get-go sustaining your character is a problem.  Mana runs out too fast, health runs out too fast, inventory fills up too fast, so many pauses and breaks are necessary.  Items that drop are of very little monetary value so building wealth can be difficult, gear from the NPC vendors is often prohibitively expensive.  Your characters progress feels very slow, leveling up takes longer than it seems like it aught to, especially early on.  Gear upgrades don't seem to help very much.
As you go on, your character seems increasingly ill equipped without going back and grinding things you already killed.  That is typically not a necessary part of an Action RPG (a gold standard to compare to in my mind would be Torchlight, where your character goes straight through without killing anything twice, and yet is always appropriately leveled and geared for the content).
These elements are all signs of half-♥♥♥♥♥ design.

There are much better Action RPGs on the market, save your money and avoid Titan Quest.

Having played main game only, not expansion: Entertaining 'Diablo'-like hack-n-slasher with intriguing real-(ancient)-world setting.

A nice-looking game with graphics and animations that hold up. A major appeal for me was seeing ancient Greece, Egypt, Babylon and China. These settings were more interesting than generic fantasy-world levels and, along with the great variety of unusual mobs, kept me motivated to see more. There is plenty of bang for the buck; my playthrough took nearly 40 hours.

Item drops and customizations are not as useful/interesting as in 'Diablo' or 'Torchlight.' On the other hand, customization is also easier to understand and perform. The skill trees offer a wide variety of character builds.

At 'normal' setting, combat was rarely challenging, then culminated in an overwhelming boss that, for me, required some cheesing to beat. I expect such balance issues are familiar to any action-RPGers. Goes with the territory.

If you're a fan of the genre, I recommend this mythological spin on 'Diablo' as a good value with an attractive, unconventional game world.

What a gem of a game! I picked this up on sale for around $5 and it is one of the best buys I've made on Steam. I will not compare it to Diablo, but it is every bit as good as other popular RPGs of the Diablo ilk. For instance, I am a fan of the Sacred games, but I actually think Titan Quest is a superior game. The story is solid; bosses are formidable; voice overs are very good; graphics are good for this type of game; weapons, upgrades, and spells are copious; skill sets are very nice; it has a decent amount of side quests without going overboard (talking to you Sacred); and the overall mechanics of the game are very smooth.

A couple of points about the game: Skill management is important as you only get to pick two skill sets out of about ten (one at level 2 and one at level 8), and then you must utilize your skill points appropriately as you will discover that some spells and attributes are more useful than others. If there is one downside in my view it is that there is no storage to stash your loot. Some may find this a plus since it induces you to manage your inventory carefully, but I found myself dropping very nice stuff to make room for other goods, and I spent way too much time debating whether to do so or not. Other than that, I have no qualms about this game.

Verdict: This is a very nice game that is well worth its price, and definitely a steal if you pick it up on sale.

I love this game, and I love this type of game.  It follows the basic lines of Diablo/Torchlight and other hack & slash games where the basis of the game is building a character from one of many classes and then collecting loot/equipment to help them succeed thru the levels.

I'm not sure if this is a complaint or if it's something that I admire in the game, or maybe a bit of both.  Basically it's almost impossible under any build to lose in the initial first two passes.  It's only the third go around where most builds fail.  Once you get into the third go around it is equipment based.  It mostly doesn't matter how well you've built the character.  With the wrong equipment, you lose.  There are a very few exceptions to this but by and large the game becomes equipment centric.

I suppose what I dislike is having invested so many hours to find the build a failure because the wrong loot dropped.  what I admire is that it actually drove me to try again.   I had played it thru numerous times (some successful, some failures) before I read anyone's builds.  The fun part of reading someone else's build is finding how they combines the different skills.  I would however suggest trying it on your own.  If your objective is simply to win. there are a couple of builds that will pretty much clean up. You won't get them from me as it's just too much of a spoiler.

And for the faint of heart who can't bring themselves to start anew, there are editors out there that allow changing just about anything - I suggest avoiding them until you've played thru at least once otherwise you'll lose what's best about the game.

A deep RPG Action game centered around Greek Mythology. Can be played alone or with online with friends. Build up one of 28 compound classes and collect weapons and armor with all kinds of effects! Battle your way through mythic lands as a one man (or woman) army and square off against ferocious monsters of all kinds! Embark on an epic journey through ancient lands and save the world from the threat of the Titans!!

Finally a hack and slash game with some actual depth. The different combinations of characters you can create is amazing, and you need to put thought into each skill point and stat allocation. The combat is generally much slower paced than games like diablo 2 or torchlight 2 and I for one am happier for it. The general mobs are tougher and instead of cutting through hundreds you are only encountering mobs of anywhere from two to twenty. Combat is satisfying once you have unlocked a few skills to make use of, and dare I say there are even tactical consierations!? Though the lack of an M rating means that there is no blood or dismemberment, the use of ragdoll physics sort of makes up for it.

The magical effects in this game are great, too many games in this genre overdo the particles and the glows and whatever else. This game keeps it basic. The special effects never get in the way of seeing what is going on.

The game world itself is amazingly detailed with grass that moves as you step through it, and water that ripples as it is disturbed. Even arrows can cause the tall grass to shake as they fly through. The little details really make this world one of the best in the genre. The lack of loading screens between locations is another thing that really makes this game feel special. It's a nice feeling actually walking into a cave or dungeon, clearing it, and then walking out seamlessly. The game world is top notch.

I do have a few issues with the user interface as it can be rather clunky at times, but it's not as terrible as some professional reviewers have made it out to be. I do highly reccomend getting some form of voice chat if you are playing with a friend in coop because the chat in game is terrible.

To sum it up this is a game that exceeds expectations for it's genre in all of the areas that matter, and in my opinion the meta critic review of 77 is nothing short of criminal.

I'm a big fan of Hack and Slashes, ever since I first touched my friend's copy of Gauntlet on the Gamecube.  My few hours I got to spend with my college buds on Diablo II were some of the best that semester.  Magicka remains on my top 10 of games this last decade.

I am also a REALLY big fan of Mythology...not kidding, when I found out that most schools didn't teach it I was heartbroken and felt sad for them, because I was lucky enough to get that amazing taste of Mythology due to my schooling.  The Big Three
date:
Greeks Egyptians and Vikings, were really good favorites of mine, but in today's world I particularly love Egyptian Mythology (in no small part due to living there) so when I found out that this game didn't JUST have accurate Greek mythical creatures to fight, I was stoked.  Definitely going to finish this.

Out of the box, here are the pros and cons!

-Pros

+Historical and Mythological Accuracy; harpies are bad guys, satyrs hate your guts, the undead are clad in bronze armor, and the like
+Diverse locals; Greece, Crete, Egypt, most of the Mediterranean is covered in this game, and more!
+HARDCORE boss fights; if you aren't prepared and have looked up some of the details on these bosses beforehand, you will get your butt kicked a lot...and in a good way, forcing you to change your tactics you like to use for other critters
+Loot; this is probably the best loot I've seen in any game, though I'm sure this is a normal thing for Hack and Slashes.  It's nice knowing that I have a ready supply of gold I can farm and go back to by getting weapons I don't need for my class and selling them at a merchant
+Class Customization; The fact that they managed to implement traditional class systems in a way that makes sense to the lore by means of class customization is the best aspect of this game.  I'm currently playing a hunter with defense and never before have I appreciated the use of a bow more in a game where my primary purpose is to be a tanky melee fighter.

Cons
-It's a bit dated...not so much to prevent fun replayability, but just enough to catch your attention.  An HD glossover of this game would be an amazing addition
-Lacking in character customization; Changing your shirt color and skin/hair color, pretty much it...kind of sad, especially since I wanted to look like either a Spartan or a Thracian in appearance.
- Class system kind of wonks out in historical accuracy; I chose hunter and defense so I could be a hoplite, my favorite historical troop choice in any Greek-themed game, and I hold my spear overhead as if I'm going to throw it...kind of a turnoff

All in all, I give this game an 8.5/10, and I will DEFINITELY update this review when I finally finish it.

reviewText: A deep RPG Action game centered around Greek Mythology. Can be played alone or with online with friends. Build up one of 28 compound classes and collect weapons and armor with all kinds of effects! Battle your way through mythic lands as a one man (or woman) army and square off against ferocious monsters of all kinds! Embark on an epic journey through ancient lands and save the world from the threat of the Titans!!

Finally a hack and slash game with some actual depth. The different combinations of characters you can create is amazing, and you need to put thought into each skill point and stat allocation. The combat is generally much slower paced than games like diablo 2 or torchlight 2 and I for one am happier for it. The general mobs are tougher and instead of cutting through hundreds you are only encountering mobs of anywhere from two to twenty. Combat is satisfying once you have unlocked a few skills to make use of, and dare I say there are even tactical consierations!? Though the lack of an M rating means that there is no blood or dismemberment, the use of ragdoll physics sort of makes up for it.

The magical effects in this game are great, too many games in this genre overdo the particles and the glows and whatever else. This game keeps it basic. The special effects never get in the way of seeing what is going on.

The game world itself is amazingly detailed with grass that moves as you step through it, and water that ripples as it is disturbed. Even arrows can cause the tall grass to shake as they fly through. The little details really make this world one of the best in the genre. The lack of loading screens between locations is another thing that really makes this game feel special. It's a nice feeling actually walking into a cave or dungeon, clearing it, and then walking out seamlessly. The game world is top notch.

I do have a few issues with the user interface as it can be rather clunky at times, but it's not as terrible as some professional reviewers have made it out to be. I do highly reccomend getting some form of voice chat if you are playing with a friend in coop because the chat in game is terrible.

To sum it up this is a game that exceeds expectations for it's genre in all of the areas that matter, and in my opinion the meta critic review of 77 is nothing short of criminal.

Having played main game only, not expansion: Entertaining 'Diablo'-like hack-n-slasher with intriguing real-(ancient)-world setting.

A nice-looking game with graphics and animations that hold up. A major appeal for me was seeing ancient Greece, Egypt, Babylon and China. These settings were more interesting than generic fantasy-world levels and, along with the great variety of unusual mobs, kept me motivated to see more. There is plenty of bang for the buck; my playthrough took nearly 40 hours.

Item drops and customizations are not as useful/interesting as in 'Diablo' or 'Torchlight.' On the other hand, customization is also easier to understand and perform. The skill trees offer a wide variety of character builds.

At 'normal' setting, combat was rarely challenging, then culminated in an overwhelming boss that, for me, required some cheesing to beat. I expect such balance issues are familiar to any action-RPGers. Goes with the territory.

If you're a fan of the genre, I recommend this mythological spin on 'Diablo' as a good value with an attractive, unconventional game world.

So I have about six hours invested in this game, so I feel like I can write a review on it at this point. So, that being said, Titan Quest is a signigicantly better game than Diablo 3. A controversial statement, sure, but I feel like it captures the magic of Diablo 2, and goes a step further and sets it in a unique setting (as far as I know, ancient Greece hasn't been used in a D2 clone other than this). Combat is very similar to Diablo 2, but I like the skill trees in this game much more (especially when you unlock your second class). The monsters are interesting, the difficulty right on point, and once the good loot starts dropping, the treasures are awesome. And most of all, it really makes good use of the Greek setting and mythology.\n\nIn other words, you should own this game and play the hell out of it. I have nothing bad to say about it except for one little thing: I wish I had the Diablo-esque storage chest in every town. But the free town portal-like ability makes it somewhat less annoying, since dumping loot is easy.

A fun jaunt through Greek Myth doesn't hurt either. If you like ARPG's but aren't sure you can wait for Diablo 3, or you need a changeup from the frankly monotonous paces of Torchlight, Titan Quest and Immortal Throne, are worth giving a first, or even second look. You might be surprised at what you find here.

Bought the gold edition of this game when it was on sale last year. Tried it when I first bought it and was a little underwhelmed so didn't put too much play time into it. Recently gave it a second a chance and am really glad I did. Would definitely go into my top five dungeon crawler games. Most other reviews cover all the positive aspects so I won't bother going into that.

My only downside to this game from my experience is that while there is a rich variety of loot to be found, I don't believe it drops often enough or consistently enough (it's the blue items I'm talking about here, the epic unique ones). No one else has mentioned this in their reviews so maybe I was just unlucky, or maybe it's just something that bothers me personally. I'm not saying the gear didn't drop for me, but the majority of it was not for my class. I can't possibly see how you can complete a five/six piece armour set with the drop rates the way that they were for me. Plus when I defeated the last boss (which I found to be fairly challenging compared to the rest of the game), not a single piece of epic loot dropped, it was just all generic useless items that weren't even worth checking as I knew my current gear would be better. So that was annoying. But as I say this might just be a pet peeve of mine and in no way damages the game.

Would definitely recommend this to anyone who is a fan of this genre.

The Gods are angry. Calamity wracks the land and ravening hordes of mythical creatures are attacking hapless tax-dodging villages all over Greece. In this hour of dire need, even the Spartan King Leonidas (taking a break from kicking innocent Persians into deep holes and prancing about in a leather jockstrap and cape) has joined forces with their ancient enemies the Greeks. Perhaps the Gods are sick of yet another Greek bailout, or perhaps the Centaurs are livid at being sold Horse Meat Lasagne. Who knows. Greece needs a mighty hero (and probably better Beef inspectors). Are you up to the challenge?\n\nPublished in 2006, TQ is an excellent Action RPG that has aged very well and a game I still play. To be properly playable, the expansion Immortal Throne is mandatory. As is the Titan Quest Fanpatch 1.17a, the Patchfix for Fanpatch 1.17, SSTQDefilerNET (RNG Function Fix, Slow Cast Fix) and TQ Vault (an out-of-game inventory management program to preserve your sanity). For truely mighty heroes, the following mods are recommended: 'm4ssboss3s-clean' and 'monsters-xmax'.
